name: Pde3b
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding and increased Pde3b activity (Kitamura et al., 1999; Onuma et al., 2002). Pde3b catalyses hydrolysis of cAMP, influencing cAMP-dependent processes. For instance, this deactivates hormone-sensitive lipase and lipolysis in adipocytes.

name: ULK1
comment: mTORC1 phosphorylates Ulk1 at Ser757, which affects the interaction between Ulk1 and AMPK (Kim et al., 2011; Shang et al., 2011). Although there is conflicting evidence about the direction and effect of this interaction, there is a consensus that this prevents autophagy when nutrients are not limiting.

name: PKA
comment: Protein kinase A (PKA) is stimulated when 1) cAMP binds the PKA regulatory subunits, dissociating them from the catalytic subunits (PKACA), and 2) PDK1 phosphorylates PKACA at T198 (Cauthron et al., 1998; Cheng et al., 1998; Moore et al., 2002). This site is found within the activation loop, generating conformational changes that lead to active PKA.

name: Brf1
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding. This impairs its role in degrading mRNA molecules that contain AU-rich elements. 14-3-3 binding also protects Brf1 from degradation, perhaps to enable rapid mRNA decay once the insulin stimulus is removed (Schmidlin et al., 2004; Benjamin et al., 2006).

name: HSF1
comment: In response to growth factors, MAPK phosphorylates HSF1 at S307, which primes GSK3 to phosphorylate at S303 (Chu et al., 1996). This promotes 14-3-3 binding, sequestering HSF1 in the cytoplasm and thus repressing its transcriptional activity (Wang et al., 2003). This represses the heat shock response during processes stimulated by growth-factors, such as cellular proliferation.

name: HSF1
comment: In response to growth factors, MAPK phosphorylates HSF1 at S307, which primes GSK3 to phosphorylate at S303 (Chu et al., 1996). This promotes 14-3-3 binding, sequestering HSF1 in the cytoplasm and thus repressing its transcriptional activity (Wang et al., 2003). This represses the heat shock response during processes stimulated by growth-factors, such as cellular proliferation.

name: HSF1
comment: In response to stresses such as heat shock, mTORC1 phosphorylates HSF1 at S326, leading to the upregulation of heat-shock proteins (e.g. Hsp70) to combat cellular stress (Chou et al., 2012).

name: Rps6
comment: p70S6K phosphorylates RPS6 (S6), a component in the 40S ribosomal subunit, at several sites, including S236 and S240 (Ferrari et al., 1991). Some studies support this results in the selective translation of a subset of mRNAs, 5'TOP mRNAs, (e.g., Jefferies et al., 1997), this remains controversial (e.g., Barth-Baus et al., 2002; Ruvinsky et al., 2005). There is also evidence that S236 phosphorylation promotes binding to the 7-methylguanosine cap-binding complex, to initiate translation (Roux et al., 2007), but studies have also shown that phosphorylation reduces protein synthesis, slows cell division, and increases cell size (e.g., Ruvinsky et al., 2005). Thus, the physiological outcome of S6 phosphorylation remains unclear.

name: Rps6
comment: p70S6K phosphorylates RPS6 (S6), a component in the 40S ribosomal subunit, at several sites, including S236 and S240 (Ferrari et al., 1991). Some studies support this results in the selective translation of a subset of mRNAs, 5'TOP mRNAs, (e.g., Jefferies et al., 1997), this remains controversial (e.g., Barth-Baus et al., 2002; Ruvinsky et al., 2005). There is also evidence that S236 phosphorylation promotes binding to the 7-methylguanosine cap-binding complex, to initiate translation (Roux et al., 2007), but studies have also shown that phosphorylation reduces protein synthesis, slows cell division, and increases cell size (e.g., Ruvinsky et al., 2005). Thus, the physiological outcome of S6 phosphorylation remains unclear.

name: Erk2
comment: MEK1/2 phosphorylates ERK1/2 within the 'activation lip', on T203/Y205 in ERK1 and T183/Y185 in ERK2 (Payne et al., 1991; Robbins et al., 1993; Butch & Guan, 1996; Her et al., 1993). Phosphorylation is favoured first on the tyrosine residue before the threonine residue (Ferrell & Bhatt, 1997; Haystead et al., 1992). This leads to activation of ERK1/2, enabling regulation of a diverse range of cellular responses to external stimuli (Roskoski, 2012). Furthermore, ERK1/2 has the ability to autophosphorylate itself at these sites (Robbins et al., 1993; Her et al., 1993), but a 'gatekeeper' site prevents this to maintain low basal ERK1/2 activity (Emrick et al., 2006).

name: Erk2
comment: MEK1/2 phosphorylates ERK1/2 within the 'activation lip', on T203/Y205 in ERK1 and T183/Y185 in ERK2 (Payne et al., 1991; Robbins et al., 1993; Butch & Guan, 1996; Her et al., 1993). Phosphorylation is favoured first on the tyrosine residue before the threonine residue (Ferrell & Bhatt, 1997; Haystead et al., 1992). This leads to activation of ERK1/2, enabling regulation of a diverse range of cellular responses to external stimuli (Roskoski, 2012). Furthermore, ERK1/2 has the ability to autophosphorylate itself at these sites (Robbins et al., 1993; Her et al., 1993), but a 'gatekeeper' site prevents this to maintain low basal ERK1/2 activity (Emrick et al., 2006).

name: Pfkfb2
comment: There is strong evidence to suggest that PFKFB2 (cardiac PFK-2) is phosphorylated at S469 and S486 by Akt, leading to 14-3-3 binding and increased activity (Deprez et al., 1997; Pozuelo et al., 2003; Moon et al., 2011). This elevates levels of its product, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, which stimulates glycolysis.

name: Pfkfb2
comment: There is strong evidence to suggest that PFKFB2 (cardiac PFK-2) is phosphorylated at S469 and S486 by Akt, leading to 14-3-3 binding and increased activity (Deprez et al., 1997; Pozuelo et al., 2003; Moon et al., 2011). This elevates levels of its product, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, which stimulates glycolysis.

name: eNOS
comment: Activates eNOS, reducing its requirement for Ca2+ and increasing production of nitric oxide. This signalling molecule plays a role in numerous processes including vasodilation (Dimmeler et al., 1999).

name: GSK3a
comment: GSK3a/b are unique kinase in that they requires its substrate to be phosphorylated at a residue +4 of the GSK3 target site. The GSK3 domain that binds this 'priming site' is occupied by the GSK3 N-terminus when S9/21 (GSK3b/a) is phosphorylated by Akt (Frame et al., 2001). This leads to disrupted GSK3 activity (Cross et al., 1995). This not only derepresses glycogen synthesis (Eldar-Finkelman et al., 1996), for which GSK3 is named, but influences a wide range of cellular processes (reviewed in Woodgett, 2001).

name: p90RSK
comment: MAPK/ERK phosphorylates p90(RSK) on several residues, including S363 (Dalby et al., 1998). This residue is found within the N-terminal kinase domain, contributing to the activation of p90(RSK).

name: TAK1
comment: Protein kinase A phosphorylates TAK1 on S439. This allows cAMP/PKA-dependent signals, such as prostaglandin E2, to enhance downstream signalling pathways, including MAPK and NF-Kb, subsequently promoting osteoclast differentiation (Kobayashi et al., 2005). This is in concordance with the role that TAK1 plays in directing differentiation away from adipogenesis (Suzawa et al., 2003).

name: Irs1
comment: Following insulin stimulation, S522 of IRS-1 is phosphorylated by S6K (Shah & Hunter, 2006), which reduces tyrosine phosphorylation of IRS-1 (Giraud et al., 2007). This provides a feedback loop to regulate insulin signalling.

name: Irs1
comment: Upon insulin stimulation, IRS-1 is phosphorylated by the insulin receptor at numerous tyrosine residues. These serve as docking sites for SH2-binding proteins. From the phosphosites shown, Y680 (and Y460 to some extent) bind the p85 subunit of PI3K (Sun et al., 1993), mediating the PI3K/Akt pathway; Y891 binds GRB2 to activate Ras/MAPK (Sun et al., 1993; Myers et al., 1994); Y1173 binds SHPTP2 to also activate Ras/MAPK (Sun et al., 1993; Noguchi et al., 1994). Thus, IRS-1 acts as a divergence point, stimulating multiple signalling pathways in response to insulin.

name: Irs1
comment: Upon insulin stimulation, IRS-1 is phosphorylated by the insulin receptor at numerous tyrosine residues. These serve as docking sites for SH2-binding proteins. From the phosphosites shown, Y680 (and Y460 to some extent) bind the p85 subunit of PI3K (Sun et al., 1993), mediating the PI3K/Akt pathway; Y891 binds GRB2 to activate Ras/MAPK (Sun et al., 1993; Myers et al., 1994); Y1173 binds SHPTP2 to also activate Ras/MAPK (Sun et al., 1993; Noguchi et al., 1994). Thus, IRS-1 acts as a divergence point, stimulating multiple signalling pathways in response to insulin.

name: Irs1
comment: Upon insulin stimulation, IRS-1 is phosphorylated by the insulin receptor at numerous tyrosine residues. These serve as docking sites for SH2-binding proteins. From the phosphosites shown, Y608 (and Y460 to some extent) bind the p85 subunit of PI3K (Sun et al., 1993), mediating the PI3K/Akt pathway; Y891 binds GRB2 to activate Ras/MAPK (Sun et al., 1993; Myers et al., 1994); Y1173 binds SHPTP2 to also activate Ras/MAPK (Sun et al., 1993; Noguchi et al., 1994). Thus, IRS-1 acts as a divergence point, stimulating multiple signalling pathways in response to insulin.

name: Irs1
comment: Upon insulin stimulation, IRS-1 is phosphorylated by the insulin receptor at numerous tyrosine residues. These serve as docking sites for SH2-binding proteins. From the phosphosites shown, Y608 (and Y460 to some extent) bind the p85 subunit of PI3K (Sun et al., 1993), mediating the PI3K/Akt pathway; Y891 binds GRB2 to activate Ras/MAPK (Sun et al., 1993; Myers et al., 1994); Y1173 binds SHPTP2 to also activate Ras/MAPK (Sun et al., 1993; Noguchi et al., 1994). Thus, IRS-1 acts as a divergence point, stimulating multiple signalling pathways in response to insulin.

name: InsR
comment: Upon binding insulin, the insulin receptor phosphorylates itself on mouse Y1175, Y1179, Y1180 (human Y1185, Y1189, and Y1190), both in vitro and in vivo (White et al., 1988; Tavaré & Denton, 1988; Kruszynska et al., 1990), leading to its activation (Murakami & Rosen, 1991) and stimulation of insulin-responsive pathways, such as glucose uptake in fat and muscle.

name: InsR
comment: Upon binding insulin, the insulin receptor phosphorylates itself on mouse Y1175, Y1179, Y1180 (human Y1185, Y1189, and Y1190), both in vitro and in vivo (White et al., 1988; Tavaré & Denton, 1988; Kruszynska et al., 1990), leading to its activation (Murakami & Rosen, 1991) and stimulation of insulin-responsive pathways, such as glucose uptake in fat and muscle.

name: InsR
comment: Upon binding insulin, the insulin receptor phosphorylates itself on mouse Y1175, Y1179, Y1180 (human Y1185, Y1189, and Y1190), both in vitro and in vivo (White et al., 1988; Tavaré & Denton, 1988; Kruszynska et al., 1990), leading to its activation (Murakami & Rosen, 1991) and stimulation of insulin-responsive pathways, such as glucose uptake in fat and muscle.

name: Grb10
comment: Enhances stability of Grb10. This reduces signalling through insulin receptor or by influencing mTORC1 instead (Hsu et al., 2011; Yu et al., 2011; ). Nevertheless, this phosphorylation site leads to feedback regulation of insulin signalling.

name: Akt
comment: Found in C-terminal hydrophobic motif. Phosphorylation at this site stimulates Akt activity (Stephens et al., 1998).

name: Akt
comment: Found in activation loop of the kinase domain. Primes Akt for second phosphorylation (at S474) for complete activation (Sarbassov et al., 2005).

name: Eif4ebp1
comment: Phosphorylation at several sites by mTORC1 (T36, T45, and T69, then S64) causes 4E-BP1 to disocciate from eIF4E. This enables eIF4E to bind the 5' cap of mRNAs, resulting in the initiation of translation (Mothe-Satney et al., 2000).

name: Eif4ebp1
comment: Phosphorylation at several sites by mTORC1 (T36, T45, and T69, then S64) causes 4E-BP1 to disocciate from eIF4E. This enables eIF4E to bind the 5' cap of mRNAs, resulting in the initiation of translation (Mothe-Satney et al., 2000).

name: Eif4ebp1
comment: Phosphorylation at several sites by mTORC1 (T36, T45, and T69, then S64) causes 4E-BP1 to disocciate from eIF4E. This enables eIF4E to bind the 5' cap of mRNAs, resulting in the initiation of translation (Mothe-Satney et al., 2000).

name: TSC2
comment: Akt phosphorylates TSC2 on several sites, including S939, S981 and T1423/62 (Manning et al., 2002; Inoki et al., 2002; Cai et al., 2006). Whilst there is conflicting evidence about whether its interaction with binding partner TSC1 is affected (Cai et al., 2006; Dan et al., 2002), studies suggest phosphorylation promotes 14-3-3 binding (Liu et al., 2002; Cai et al., 2006), cytoplasmic localisation (Cai et al., 2006), and ultimately its degradation (Inoki et al., 2002; Dan et al., 2002). This derepresses mTORC1 activity, promoting protein and lipid synthesis in response to mitogenic and nutrient stimuli.

name: TSC2
comment: Akt phosphorylates TSC2 on several sites, including S939, S981 and T1423/62 (Manning et al., 2002; Inoki et al., 2002; Cai et al., 2006). Whilst there is conflicting evidence about whether its interaction with binding partner TSC1 is affected (Cai et al., 2006; Dan et al., 2002), studies suggest phosphorylation promotes 14-3-3 binding (Liu et al., 2002; Cai et al., 2006), cytoplasmic localisation (Cai et al., 2006), and ultimately its degradation (Inoki et al., 2002; Dan et al., 2002). This derepresses mTORC1 activity, promoting protein and lipid synthesis in response to mitogenic and nutrient stimuli.

name: TSC2
comment: Akt phosphorylates TSC2 on several sites, including S939, S981 and T1443/1465 (Manning et al., 2002; Inoki et al., 2002; Cai et al., 2006). Whilst there is conflicting evidence about whether its interaction with binding partner TSC1 is affected (Cai et al., 2006; Dan et al., 2002), studies suggest phosphorylation promotes 14-3-3 binding (Liu et al., 2002; Cai et al., 2006), cytoplasmic localisation (Cai et al., 2006), and ultimately its degradation (Inoki et al., 2002; Dan et al., 2002). This derepresses mTORC1 activity, promoting protein and lipid synthesis in response to mitogenic and nutrient stimuli.

name: Mekk3
comment: SGK1 phosphorylates MEKK3 (MAP3K3) on S337 (and S166), reducing its kinase activity (Chun et al., 2003). Since MEKK3 regulates the stress-activated (SAPK) and mitogen-activated (MAPK) protein kinase pathways, this provides a way for SGK1 to turn off these pathways, enabling cross-talk between kinase signalling pathways.

name: NHE1
comment: NHE1 is phosphorylated at this site by p90(RSK). Promotes 14-3-3 binding (Lehoux et al., 2001), leading to increased Na+/H+ exchange and cell alkalinisation (Takahashi et al., 1999). Whilst this has been shown to exacerbate myocardial ischemia and reperfusion injury (Maekawa et al., 2006), it may also be necessary for cell cycle progression (Meima et al., 2009).

name: BAD
comment: In a PKC-dependent manner, p90RSK phosphorylates this site. This promotes14-3-3 binding, blocking BAD from heterodimerising with Bcl-XL, thus promoting cell survival and inhibiting apoptosis (Zha et al., 1996; Tan et al., 1999).

name: BAD
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding preventing BAD from heterodimerising with Bcl-XL, promoting cell survival and inhibiting apoptosis (Zha et al., 1996; Datta et al., 1997).

name: SOS1
comment: MAP kinase (MAPK) phosphorylates SOS1 on several sites, including S1178, S1183, S1197, which causes disassociation of the Sos1-Grb2 complex (Corbalan-Garcia et al., 1996). Since Sos1-Grb2 connects receptor tyrosine kinases to Ras and MAPK downstream, this serves as a feedback mechanism for Ras/MAPK signalling (e.g., Cherniack et al., 1995).

name: SOS1
comment: MAP kinase (MAPK) phosphorylates SOS1 on several sites, including S1178, S1183, S1197, which causes disassociation of the Sos1-Grb2 complex (Corbalan-Garcia et al., 1996). Since Sos1-Grb2 connects receptor tyrosine kinases to Ras and MAPK downstream, this serves as a feedback mechanism for Ras/MAPK signalling (e.g., Cherniack et al., 1995).

name: SOS1
comment: MAP kinase (MAPK) phosphorylates SOS1 on several sites, including S1178, S1183, S1197, which causes disassociation of the Sos1-Grb2 complex (Corbalan-Garcia et al., 1996). Since Sos1-Grb2 connects receptor tyrosine kinases to Ras and MAPK downstream, this serves as a feedback mechanism for Ras/MAPK signalling (e.g., Cherniack et al., 1995).

name: Ndrg1
comment: SGK kinases phosphorylate T328, S330, T346, T356, and T366 of NDRG1 (the latter three found within a triple 10-residue repeat sequence) (Murray et al., 2004; Murakami et al., 2010). This primes NDRG1 for phosphorylation by GSK3 (Murray et al., 2004). Phosphorylation of NDRG1 influences its role in stress responses, such as the suppression of NF-Kb signalling and CXC chemokine production (Murakami et al., 2010).

name: Ndrg1
comment: SGK kinases phosphorylate T328, S330, T346, T356, and T366 of NDRG1 (the latter three found within a triple 10-residue repeat sequence) (Murray et al., 2004; Murakami et al., 2010). This primes NDRG1 for phosphorylation by GSK3 (Murray et al., 2004). Phosphorylation of NDRG1 influences its role in stress responses, such as the suppression of NF-Kb signalling and CXC chemokine production (Murakami et al., 2010).

name: Erk1
comment: MEK1/2 phosphorylates ERK1/2 within the 'activation lip', on T203/Y205 in ERK1 and T183/Y185 in ERK2 (Payne et al., 1991; Robbins et al., 1993; Butch & Guan, 1996; Her et al., 1993). Phosphorylation is favoured first on the tyrosine residue before the threonine residue (Ferrell & Bhatt, 1997; Haystead et al., 1992). This leads to activation of ERK1/2, enabling regulation of a diverse range of cellular responses to external stimuli (Roskoski, 2012). Furthermore, ERK1/2 has the ability to autophosphorylate itself at these sites (Robbins et al., 1993; Her et al., 1993), but a 'gatekeeper' site prevents this to maintain low basal ERK1/2 activity (Emrick et al., 2006).

name: Erk1
comment: MEK1/2 phosphorylates ERK1/2 within the 'activation lip', on T203/Y205 in ERK1 and T183/Y185 in ERK2 (Payne et al., 1991; Robbins et al., 1993; Butch & Guan, 1996; Her et al., 1993). Phosphorylation is favoured first on the tyrosine residue before the threonine residue (Ferrell & Bhatt, 1997; Haystead et al., 1992). This leads to activation of ERK1/2, enabling regulation of a diverse range of cellular responses to external stimuli (Roskoski, 2012). Furthermore, ERK1/2 has the ability to autophosphorylate itself at these sites (Robbins et al., 1993; Her et al., 1993), but a 'gatekeeper' site prevents this to maintain low basal ERK1/2 activity (Emrick et al., 2006).

name: Eif4b
comment: p70S6K phosphorylates Ei4b at this site, which promotes association with eIF3 scaffold in the translation preinitiation complex. Here, eIF4A enhances the helicase activity of eIF4A, melting inhibitory secondary structures in the 5'UTR of mRNAs. This enables the 40S ribosomal subunit to bind and initiate translation (Raught et al., 2004; Holz et al., 2005).

name: Sin1
comment: Akt phosphorylates SIN1, a component of the mTORC2 complex. This activates mTORC2 - amongst its substrates is Akt, thus potentiating a feed-forward signalling loop (Humphrey et al., 2013).

name: p70S6K
comment: mTORC1 phosphorylates S6K-p70 at T412 (Pearson et al., 1995; Han et al., 1995), found within a hydrophobic motif downstream of the catalytic domain. This its phosphorylation of 40S ribosomal protein S6, to activate protein synthesis.

name: AS160
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding (although T649 is primary binding site). Disrupts GTPase-activating (GAP) function of AS160 and promotes translocation of GLUT4 glucose transporter to the plasma membrane, increasing glucose uptake (Sano et al., 2003; Ramm et al., 2006; Geraghty et al., 2007).

name: AS160
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding (although T649 is primary binding site). Disrupts GTPase-activating (GAP) function of AS160 and promotes translocation of GLUT4 glucose transporter to the plasma membrane, increasing glucose uptake (Sano et al., 2003; Ramm et al., 2006; Geraghty et al., 2007).

name: AS160
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding (although T649 is primary binding site). Disrupts GTPase-activating (GAP) function of AS160 and promotes translocation of GLUT4 glucose transporter to the plasma membrane, increasing glucose uptake (Sano et al., 2003; Ramm et al., 2006; Geraghty et al., 2007).

name: AS160
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding (although T649 is primary binding site). Disrupts GTPase-activating (GAP) function of AS160 and promotes translocation of GLUT4 glucose transporter to the plasma membrane, increasing glucose uptake (Sano et al., 2003; Ramm et al., 2006; Geraghty et al., 2007).

name: MSK1
comment: The mitogen- and stress-activated kinase 1 (MSK1) is initially phosphorylated by p38 MAPK and ERK1 (Markou & Lazou, 2002; McCoy et al., 2005), including on residue T645 (human T581), this enables MSK1 to autophosphorylate: the C-terminal kinase domain phosphorylates itself at several sites, including the hydrophobic motif at S375 (human S376). This activates the N-terminal kinase domain, enabling MSK1 to phosphorylate its substrates (McCoy et al., 2005). This enables the cell to respond to both growth factors and cellular stress through the same kinase (e.g., Deak et al., 1998).

name: Hsl
comment: PKA phosphorylates HSL on several residues. This results in the activation of HSL, promoting lipolysis and thus mobilisation of energy stores during exercise or starvation (Anthonsen et al., 1998; Krintel et al., 2008).

name: Hsl
comment: AMPK phosphorylates mouse S559 (rat S565) (Garton et al., 1989). Phosphorylation of S559 is present in the 'basal' state (in the absence of lipolytic stimuli) and has little effect on HSL activity (Garton et al., 1989; Donsmark et al., 2004; Roepstorff et al., 2004). There is some evidence that it reduces phosphorylation at mouse S557 (rat S563) by PKA (Watt et al., 2006; Garton et al., 1989; Garton & Yeaman, 1990), which is needed for HSL activity in mediating lipolysis (Shen et al., 1998).

name: Plin1
comment: Protein kinase A phosphorylates Plin1 (perilipin A) at S492, which promotes access of lipases to lipid droplets in adipocytes, leading to lipid droplet breakdown and lipolysis (Marcinkiewicz et al., 2006; Miyoshi et al., 2007). This serves to mobilise energy during fasting and exercise.

name: Edc3
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding, which impairs its role in mRNA decay and translation repression at p-bodies (Larance et al., 2010). This provides one avenue for insulin to increase protein synthesis.

name: Pras40
comment: Akt phosphorylates PRAS40 at T247 (Kovacina et al., 2003; Sancak et al., 2007; Vander et al., 2007), which promotes mTORC1 to phosphorylate PRAS40 at multiple sites, including S184 (Nascimento et al., 2010; Oshiro et al., 2007). Together, these phosphorylation events cause PRAS40 to dissociate from mTORC1 and bind 14-3-3. Combined with Akt-mediated TSC2 phosphorylation, this results in mTORC1 activation.

name: Pras40
comment: Akt phosphorylates PRAS40 at T247 (Kovacina et al., 2003; Sancak et al., 2007; Vander et al., 2007), which promotes mTORC1 to phosphorylate PRAS40 at multiple sites, including S184 (Nascimento et al., 2010; Oshiro et al., 2007). Together, these phosphorylation events cause PRAS40 to dissociate from mTORC1 and bind 14-3-3. Combined with Akt-mediated TSC2 phosphorylation, this results in mTORC1 activation.

name: mTOR
comment: Upon activation, mTOR autophosphorylates itself on S2481 (Peterson et al., 2000), being observed in both complexes mTORC1 and mTORC2 (Soliman et al., 2010). Although diagonistic of mTOR activity, the physiological significance of this autophosphorylation site remains elusive.

name: mTOR
comment: Originally considered an Akt target (Sekulić et al., 2000; Navé et al., 1999), more recent evidence suggests that S2448 is actually phosphorylated by p70-S6K (Chiang & Abraham, 2005; Holz & Blenis, 2005). This presents a feedback loop, although its function has not been elucidated. Since S2448 lies within the repressor domain, it has been speculated that phosphorylation at this site represses mTOR activity (Sekulić et al., 2000), but does not affect mTORC1 complex formation (Rosner et al., 2010).

name: Ndrg2
comment: SGK kinases phosphorylate T330, S332, and T348 of NDRG2 - there is some evidence that this primes NDRG2 for phosphorylation by GSK3 (Murray et al., 2004). The functional consequences of this have not been well-studied.

name: Ndrg2
comment: SGK kinases phosphorylate T330, S332, and T348 of NDRG2 - there is some evidence that this primes NDRG2 for phosphorylation by GSK3 (Murray et al., 2004). The functional consequences of this have not been well-studied.

name: GSK3b
comment: GSK3a/b are unique kinase in that they requires its substrate to be phosphorylated at a residue +4 of the GSK3 target site. The GSK3 domain that binds this 'priming site' is occupied by the GSK3 N-terminus when S9/21 (GSK3b/a) is phosphorylated by Akt (Frame et al., 2001). This leads to disrupted GSK3 activity (Cross et al., 1995). This not only derepresses glycogen synthesis (Eldar-Finkelman et al., 1996), for which GSK3 is named, but influences a wide range of cellular processes (reviewed in Woodgett, 2001).

name: Foxo3a
comment: Promotes 14-3-3 binding and subsequent export from the nucleus. This prevents its regulation of target genes, including those involved in apoptosis (Brunet et al., 1999; Brunet et al., 2002).

name: Gys
comment: GSK3 phosphorylates Gys at consecutive serines (S641, S645, S649, S653) in a C->N direction (Embi et al., 1980; Rylatt et al., 1980). Once S641 is phosphorylated, Gys activity is reduced, now depending on glucose-6-phosphate for allosteric activation (Skurat & Roach, 1995; Wang & Roach, 1993). Upon insulin stimulation, GSK3 is inhibited, de-repressing Gys and thus stimulating glycogen synthesis (Schafer et al., 2004; Roach et al., 2012).

name: Gys
comment: GSK3 phosphorylates Gys at consecutive serines (S641, S645, S649, S653) in a C->N direction (Embi et al., 1980; Rylatt et al., 1980). Once S641 is phosphorylated, Gys activity is reduced, now depending on glucose-6-phosphate for allosteric activation (Skurat & Roach, 1995; Wang & Roach, 1993). Upon insulin stimulation, GSK3 is inhibited, de-repressing Gys and thus stimulating glycogen synthesis (Schafer et al., 2004; Roach et al., 2012).
